Hi Andy, 

I am sorry, but I didn't understand what you mean by "hypercube =
input 
topology"? 
As far as I know, this is simply a CPPN taking 2 points =
from the 
substrate space (connective CPPN) instead of only one (spatial CP=
PN). 
The coordinates of this points in the substrate space are the inputs =

to this CPPN and the output is the weight/point intensity. 
The topology b=
etween these inputs and the output node is evolved with 
the regular NEAT m=
ethod. The evolved topology and the weights are the 
most important thing t=
o consider. 
I guess this topology can change? Maybe in time (leaky neurons=
) or 
with recurrent connections?
The idea of changing input topology for t=
he CPPN is like 
HyperHyperNEAT :) CPPNs that further create CPPNs..

Peter=


--- In neat@yahoogroups.com, "afcarl2" <a.carl@...> wrote:
>
> Ken,
> 
> =
   It appears that you keep attempting to recast the substrate 
inputs 
> a=
nd outputs such that the hypercube input topology remains 
constant. 
> Not=
 taking anything away from HyperNEAT's ability to exploit 
1d/2d/3d 
> geom=
etry in which the hypercube input topology remains constant, 
the 
> more g=
eneral question of when the hypercube input topology is not 
> constant, wh=
at do you do? Please address this specific issue. The 
> answer to this que=
stion will help to identify the 
> applicability/limitations of HyperNEAT.
=
> 
> Thanks,
>    Andy Carl
>

tanley" <kstanley@> wrote:

ghlights an important 
area

won't know until we do some

> > 
> >=
 To give some of my thoughts, perhaps the most obvious thing is 
> similar =

> > to what you suggest:  Have two separate input sets, one for 
> the "ty=
pe A 
> > info" and one for "type B info."  
> > 
> > The way this would lo=
ok is e.g. if A was 2D and B was 2D then the 
> CPPN 
> > would have 4 inpu=
ts, 2 represent A source nodes and 2 
representing 
> B 
> > soource nodes.=

> > 
> > Then, I would still have only one set of outputs.  I am still a 
=
> little 
> > unclear on why you say the outputs are from the second 
subst=
rate?  
> In 
> > my understanding, this is still all one substrate, it's j=
ust that 
> it 
> > collects inputs from two different sources.  But it can=
 still 
exist 
> > with only one set of outputs.  So if the outputs are 2D,=
 the CPPN 
> would 
> > have 2 more inputs representing the output area for=
 a total of 6 
> inputs 
> > (and one output representing the weight of a c=
onnection in the 
> > substrate).
> > 
> > If there was a hidden layer you =
could have it exist in either the 
> same 
> > geometry as A, the same geom=
etry as B, or the same geometry as 
the 
> > outputs.  (For example by intr=
oducing a z dimension to any of 
> these)  
> > Or you could have each kind=
 of hidden layer all at once.
> > 
> > Of course, as you note, there are a =
lot of ways to do something 
> like 
> > this.  I think it will be a great =
issue to explore, but it may 
> require 
> > starting with a very simple do=
main that isolates the issue (i.e. 
> > orthogonal input types) so we can c=
oncentrate on that rather than 
> on a 
> > specific domain with its own co=
mplications.
> > 
> > One other issue to note is that even if two sets of i=
nputs are in 
> > effect unrelated, it may not necessarily hurt antyhing to=
 put 
them 
> in 
> > the same geometry.  For example, they could be two se=
parate 
planes 
> in 
> > the same cube.  On the face of it, it seems like =
that could cause 
> > problems, but we don't yet know whether the situation=
 is that 
> difficult 
> > to deal with in practice.  There could also be h=
idden 
relationships 
> > that are not obvious but still exploitable in a s=
urprising way.
